Description:
Women face a number of challenges during their parenting years.

The decision to stay home or continue working is not clear-cut. Whether a woman can “have it all” depends on her personal aspirations and values; the best way to design your own version of having it all is to be armed with information and develop the right plan for your career going forward.
ShortDesc: Women face a number of challenges during their parenting years.
Title: Motherhood and Your Professional Identity: Career Planning Strategies for Your Parenting Years

Description:
The purpose of Edward Henkel’s MovementTalks is to show how dance can be used as a catalyst for change in the world.

“Shell Shock: Dance Serves Veterans of War” highlights the work of Exit12, founded by veteran Roman Baca. Upon his return from Iraq, Baca developed a dance program that brings together professional dancers and former combatants who are open to the idea of recalibrating their lives through a dance experience. Exit12's veteran-civilian movement workshop creates movement from experiences, veteran or civilian, either personal or shared. It instills a reconnection to personal identity, and repurposes violent movement by creating awareness of intention. The workshops are designed to engage groups in movement creation, self-esteem building, empathy enrichment and teamwork.

Program:

  • MovementTalks’ Edward Henkel interviews Exit12 Founder Roman Baca.
  • Exit12 will demonstrate workshop techniques with four veterans in NYC. (Edward Henkel will follow these technique demonstrations with questions for Baca and the veterans)
  • Performances (performed by professional dancers): Sometimes, Silence - choreographed by an Army mom, Angela Scimonelli. A profile of watching her sons grow up, enlist and get deployed to fight in Afghanistan. Score was composed by her brother Paul Scimonelli, a former Marine in the Marine Band.
    Conflict(ed) - a work that contrasts the military and Middle Eastern cultures.
    Aggressed/This is War - two movement studies performed alongside the poetry of USMC Combat Veteran William Michael Day, detailing the horrors of combat and the difficult return home.
    Yarjuun - "they hope" in Arabic, Yarjuun was choreographed in Iraq with students from Erbil and Kirkuk during a cultural diplomacy workshop.
  • Testimonials from veterans about their participation in the Exit12 program.

Description:
William Ury, coauthor of the negotiator’s bible, Getting to Yes, and cofounder of Harvard’s program on negotiation, has taught tens of thousands of people from all walks of life how to negotiate their way to success.

The biggest obstacle he’s encountered is our own natural tendency to react in ways that don’t serve our true interests. Ury shares his revolutionary method—revealed in his new book, Getting to Yes with Yourself—for turning this obstacle into an opportunity, dramatically improving outcomes in all aspects of life.

There will be a selling and signing of William Ury's new book, Getting to Yes with Yourself, following the event.

Description:
The global economy is in crisis—recovery from the '08 crash is slow and most major economies are in trouble.

Is global political crisis the outcome of  economic crisis? How will the future of globalization affect China, Russia, the Euro-zone and Japan? Are Middle East economies failing? How will the U S economy perform and can America remain # 1? Can the world economy recover?

Noted scholar and foreign affairs analyst Michael Mandelbaum, author of the bestselling new book The Road to Global Prosperity, discusses these issues with Professor Ralph Buultjens.

A bookselling and signing of Michael Mandelbaum’s The Road to Global Prosperity will follow the program.

Due to the fast-changing nature of global politics, topics may change.

 

Can't make it to the event? Leave your questions for our guests below, and they might be used on stage during the Q&A. Keep an eye on 92Y On Demand after the event for any video clips we might share! You might see your question used on stage.

Description:
For more than 15 years, 92Y audiences have relished the clarity and thoughtfulness Professor Ralph Buultjens brings to discussions of foreign affairs.

Drawing on his vast knowledge and understanding of how conflicts in one part of the world affect peace in another, Buultjens offers insight  you can’t find anywhere else. Due to the fast-changing nature of global politics, topics may change.

 

Can't make it to the event? Leave your questions for our guests below, and they might be used on stage during the Q&A. Keep an eye on 92Y On Demand after the event for any video clips we might share! You might see your question used on stage.

 
 

Brief Bio

Ralph Buultjens is a professor at New York University and the former Nehru Professor/Professorial Fellow at the University of Cambridge. He was awarded the Toynbee Prize for Social Sciences and is the author of 10 books on world affairs.

Description:
Chuck Todd is the Chief White House Correspondent and Political Director of NBC News, and a contributing editor to "Meet the Press."

He also serves as NBC News' on-air political analyst for "NBC Nightly News with Brian Williams," "Today," "Meet the Press" and such MSNBC programs as "Morning Joe" and "Hardball with Chris Matthews." Before joining NBC News, Todd was editor-in-chief of National Journal's "The Hotline," Washington's premier daily briefing on America politics. He has also written Op-Ed pieces for The New York Times and the Washington Post and for the Atlantic Monthly, where he is a contributing editor. He is the co-author of How Barack Obama Won: A State-by-State Guide to the Historic 2008 Presidential Election. He teaches a graduate political communications course at Johns Hopkins University. His newest book is The Stranger: Barack Obama in the White House.

Jeff Greenfield is one of the sharpest, wittiest minds around when it comes to discussing politics, current events and media.

Description:
Barney Frank discusses his journey from Bayonne, New Jersey to the U.S. Congress, where he played a vital role in the struggle for personal freedom and economic fairness.

He'll talk about his fight for gay rights and his lifelong struggle against inequality—from his early civil rights advocacy in the Massachusetts State Legislature to his instrumental role as Chairman of the House Financial Services Committee. From the Clinton impeachment to the economic meltdown of 2008 to the repeal of Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell, Frank’s words and deeds mattered.  He's the author of a new memoir, Frank.

Barney Frank will be signing copies of his new book, Frank, following the event.

Description:
Join acclaimed YA writer Marissa Meyer as she discusses her popular Lunar Chronicles series, with the highly-anticipated release of Fairest: Levana’s Story.

Fans of the Lunar Chronicles know Queen Levana as a ruler who uses her “glamour” to gain power. But long before she crossed paths with Cinder, Scarlet and Cress, Levana lived a very different story—a story that has never been told . . . until now. Meyer spins yet another unforgettable tale about love and war, deceit and death. Don’t miss this chance to hear Marissa Meyer discuss the inspiration behind Levana’s characterization.

A book signing will follow the event. Books will be available for purchase courtesy of Books of Wonder.

Take advantage of our 35 and Under pricing ($15!).

Description:
Paul Muldoon Photo Credit: Pieter M. van Hattem

A Valentine from Four Distinguished Writers Talking About Our Favorite Emotion.

In a way, love is a writer's only subject, though it usually is disguised by, or filtered through, such matters as war, rebellion, heroism, zeal, ambition, madness, avarice, grief, wonder, innocence, shame and so forth. Under every  subject a writer deals with lies love of someone or of something. Even when no motive for writing shows—and in the best works or art it ought not to—still, most writers are out to make the world worth loving. Don't you think? This is the sort of question Erica Jong, Alice McDermott, Paul Muldoon and Roger Rosenblatt will toss to one another, with Valentine's Day around the corner, in a free-wheeling discussion among celebrated writers whose fiction, essays and poems have made them beloved themselves. Romantic love, parental love, love of friends, of nature, of love itself—every angle and permutation examined, embraced and knocked about. What's not to love. Oh, did we fail to mention sex?

 

Can't make it to the event? Leave your questions for our guests below, and they might be used on stage during the Q&A. Keep an eye on 92Y On Demand after the event for any video clips we might share! You might see your question used on stage.
ShortDesc: A Valentine from Four Distinguished Writers Talking About Our Favorite Emotion.
Title: What We Write About When We Write About Love

Description:
Barry and male dancers talk about why they dance and what is their basic motivation.

Barry’s guests dance, show excerpts of male dancers on video, and will engage the audience in simple movements that reflect the power that men bring to dance.
ShortDesc: Barry and male dancers talk about why they dance and what is their basic motivation.
Title: Edward Henkel's MovementTalks: Real Men Dance—We’ve Come a Long Way Baby

Description:
Kathleen and panelists bring their expertise in the area of finding meaningful intersections between dance education and technology to enliven students learning in dance artistry and education life with students demonstrating how they work on projects.

As Kathleen says about her work at Hunter College, “We’re exploring how dance technique and technology intersect in mindful and innovative ways, through the Arnhold iDanceEd initiative.” In meaningful, effective ways including K-12, higher education, distance learning and special needs populations, the panel remains continuously inspired by so many people doing amazing work.
ShortDesc: Kathleen and panelists bring their expertise in the area of finding meaningful intersections between dance education and technology to enliven students learning in dance artistry and education life with students demonstrating how they work on projects.
Title: Edward Henkel's MovementTalks: Dance and Technology in Education

Description: Susan Slotnick, Director of Figures In Flight, and Andre Noel, Director of Figures In Flight Released, perform with their students and companies and talk about how dance is working in the prison culture and it’s potential for salvaging the lives of youth at risk.
ShortDesc: Susan Slotnick, Director of Figures In Flight, and Andre Noel, Director of Figures In Flight Released, perform with their students and companies and talk about how dance is working in the prison culture and it’s potential for salvaging the lives of youth at risk.
Title: Edward Henkel's MovementTalks: Dance and Youth at Risk

Description:
When Abraham Lincoln delivered what has been called his greatest speech, Union victory was within days and slavery was coming to an end.

Yet this elegiac address – drawing heavily on scriptural verses – seeks to understand the role of Divine providence in the conflict and a desire to “bind up the nation’s wounds.” On the occasion of Lincoln’s 150th yahrzeit, Yossi Prager offers an in-depth look at the Second Inaugural.

 

Brief Bio

Yossi Prager is the Executive Director for North America of The AVI CHAI Foundation. He has edited a book on Judaism and philanthropy entitled Toward a Renewed Ethic of Jewish Philanthropy and has been published in Tradition, Jewish Action, Philanthropy Magazine, The New York Jewish Week and other publications.
ShortDesc: When Abraham Lincoln delivered what has been called his greatest speech, Union victory was within days and slavery was coming to an end.
Title: What the Second Inaugural Address Teaches About Lincoln’s Religious Worldview and Our Own

Description:
Join us as we explore Jewish texts, from biblical roots to modern literature, which provide multiple views of mothers, their roles and their power.

As the first woman Vice Chancellor at Jewish Theological Seminary, Dr. Anne Lapidus Lerner has been both an activist and a scholar in the fields of Jewish women’s studies and Jewish literature. Her career on the JTS faculty and her position as a Research Associate at the Hadassah-Brandeis Institute recognize her contribution to the field as does her highly acclaimed study of Eve, Eternally Eve.
ShortDesc: Join us as we explore Jewish texts, from biblical roots to modern literature, which provide multiple views of mothers, their roles and their power.
Title: Motherhood and Matriarchy: Original Jewish Mothers

Description:

He will discuss historic efforts and the future of diplomacy in achieving a sustainable peace between Israel, the Palestinians and her Arab neighbors.

There will be bookselling and signing of Roger Cohen’s new book, The Girl from Human Street, following the event.

 

Can't make it to the event? Leave your questions for our guests below, and they might be used on stage during the Q&A. Keep an eye on 92Y On Demand after the event for any video clips we might share! You might see your question used on stage.

Description:
There are a bewildering number of specialists who diagnose and treat children with psychiatric and learning disorders and a wide range of treatments available ranging from behavioral to psychopharmacological.

Rachel Busman, PsyD, and Natalie Weder, MD, of the Child Mind Institute will take parents through the steps to find the best professional to help their child. Parents will also learn what to look for to ensure that they're getting quality care and which questions to ask to evaluate both the clinicians and types of treatments they offer.

This workshop is for parents of children ages 4-8.
ShortDesc: There are a bewildering number of specialists who diagnose and treat children with psychiatric and learning disorders and a wide range of treatments available ranging from behavioral to psychopharmacological.
Title: Mental Health GPS: Navigating Diagnosis and Treatment

Description:
While many kids are lucky enough to become best of friends with their sibling, it is normal for siblings to fight, at least some of the time.

Jealousy, competition and fighting between siblings, commonly known as sibling rivalry, is a common concern for most parents. David Anderson, PhD, Senior Director of the ADHD and Disruptive Behavior Disorders Center at the Child Mind Institute, will explore what children fight about, the effects it has on parents and how to manage sibling situations in a calm and controlled way while allowing the children to develop lifetime skills in communication and relationship building.

This workshop is for parents of children ages 3-14.
ShortDesc: While many kids are lucky enough to become best of friends with their sibling, it is normal for siblings to fight, at least some of the time.
Title: Sibling Rivalry: How to Keep the Peace at Home

Description:
One of the key players in the historic campaign that made Barack Obama President, David Axelrod has been involved with some of the greatest political changes of the last decade.

Axelrod has devoted a lifetime to questioning political certainties and to bringing fresh thinking into the political landscape.

Join him as he discusses his remarkable career from young journalist to political consultant and ultimately senior advisor to the President along with his views on the most pressing issues facing the United States today.

David Axelrod will sign copies of his new book, Believer: My Forty Years in Politics, after the talk. Books will be available for purchase.

 

Can't make it to the event? Leave your questions for our guests below, and they might be used on stage during the Q&A. Keep an eye on 92Y On Demand after the event for any video clips we might share! You might see your question used on stage.

 
 

Brief Bio

David Remnick, editor of The New Yorker since July 1998, began his reporting career at The Washington Post in 1982. He is the author of several books, including The Bridge: The Life and Rise of Barack Obama, King of the World, Resurrection and Lenin’s Tomb, for which he received both the Pulitzer Prize for nonfiction and a George Polk Award for excellence in journalism. He became a staff writer at The New Yorker in 1992 and has since written over a hundred pieces for the magazine. In 2000, Remnick was named Advertising Age’s Editor of the Year. Since Remnick became editor, The New Yorker has won numerous National Magazine Awards.
ShortDesc: One of the key players in the historic campaign that made Barack Obama President, David Axelrod has been involved with some of the greatest political changes of the last decade.
Title: David Axelrod in Conversation with David Remnick—Believer: My Forty Years in Politics

Description:
Almost everything made today is done so digitally, as to look polished and perfect. 

Companies like Apple have succeeded in creating products that have no seams and appear robotically made. For a ceramicist, using the wheel allows the maker to erase any evidence of the human hand. The origins of data reproduction always involved a wheel or disc. By shunning the wheel and then building by hand, the artist shows the fingerprints in the work— something Apple cannot and will never be able to do. Sachs employs this practice in all his work, and recently, has been using it in ceramics fired at the 92nd St Y. His tea bowls, inspired by Japanese chawan, are built using the oldest pinch-pot method, and his other sculptures show the scars of his labor. The dents, cracks and errors are evident in the handmade and are what make the product the result of an individual.

This event is a LIVE event taking place in our Buttenwieser Hall and will be available online only as On-Demand content at a later date.

 

Brief Bio

Tom Sachs is a sculptor, probably best known for his elaborate dub-versions of various icons of Modernism—all of them masterpieces of engineering and design of one kind or another. A lot has been made of the conceptual underpinnings of these sculptures: how Sachs samples capitalist culture: remixing, dubbing and spitting it back out again, so that the results are transformed and transforming. Equally, if not more important, is his total embrace of "showing his work." All the steps that led up to the end result are always on display. This means that nothing Sachs makes is ever finished. Like any good engineering project, everything can always be stripped down, stripped out, redesigned and improved.

 

This event is part of 92Ys Virtual Clay™ series: offering first of a kind, real-time online classes that gather a vibrant community of artists, designers and art historians to speak with you about important topics in ceramics. The conversations are meant to challenge preconceptions and explore new territory, inspiring you to think about the world in fresh and different ways. All of this in the comfort of your home, studio or classroom.

 

With support by:

Description:
Sustainability is more than just a trend—it is the future of design.

As our world changes socially, economically and industrially, the benefits of eco-friendly design are increasingly important. World-renowned interior designer and architect Campion Platt’s projects are a mix of fine craftsmanship and contemporary styling, with a particular eye to eco-friendly consciousness. Join Platt, a favorite designer among celebrities such as Al Pacino, Meg Ryan, Roger Waters, Conan O’Brien and socialite Anne Hearst, as he shares many high- and low-tech ways to improve the way we live—by increasing energy efficiency, reducing our waste and using renewable materials.
ShortDesc: Sustainability is more than just a trend—it is the future of design.
Title: Sustainable Architecture: The Future of Design

Description:
Should you remove gluten from your diet? It depends!

The director of the Celiac Disease Center at Columbia, Dr. Peter H. R. Green, reveals what you need to know about celiac disease, what it has to do with your immune system and how to detect its symptoms to determine what you may be giving up when you give up gluten unnecessarily.

 

Brief Bio

Peter H. R. Green, MD, Phyllis & Ivan Seidenberg Professor of Medicine, Columbia University and Director, Celiac Disease Center at Columbia University. Dr. Green received his medical degree from University of Sydney, Australia. Celiac disease and gluten related disorders has been Dr. Green’s focus over the last 30 years with equal concentration on patient care and research. He is one of the few physicians in the United States with an intense clinical and academic interest and expertise in celiac disease. Dr. Green established the Celiac Disease Center at Columbia University and is co-author of the book Celiac Disease: A Hidden Epidemic.
ShortDesc: Should you remove gluten from your diet? It depends!
Title: Gluten: What’s All the Fuss About?

Description:
Image Credit: Henri Matisse (French, 1869-1954). Memory of Oceania (Souvenir d’Océanie), summer 1952–early 1953. Gouache on paper, cut and pasted, and charcoal on paper, mounted on canvas. 112 x 112 7/8” (284.4 x 286.4 cm). The Museum of Modern Art, New York. Mrs Simon Guggenheim Fund, 1968. © 2014 Succession H. Matisse / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

On view at MoMA through Feb 8, Henri Matisse: The Cut-Outs is the most comprehensive exhibition of Matisse’s cut-outs ever mounted.

Join curator Samantha Friedman for her unique insights as she discusses Matisse’s invention of this radical new form of art in the last decade of his career. 

 

Brief Bio

Samantha Friedman is an Assistant Curator in the Department of Drawings and Prints at The Museum of Modern Art, New York. In addition to co-curating Henri Matisse: The Cut-Outs (with Jodi Hauptman, Senior Curator and Karl Buchberg, Senior Conservator, 2014), she has organized Van Gogh, Dalí, and Beyond: The World Reimagined (2013), and Exquisite Corpses: Drawing and Disfiguration (2012), and, with Jodi Hauptman, Fast Forward: Modern Moments, 1913-2013 (2013), Picasso to Warhol: Fourteen Modern Masters (2011-12), and Stage Pictures: Drawing for Performance (2009). She has authored multiple essays for these exhibitions’ catalogues, as well as the children’s book Matisse’s Garden (MoMA, 2014). She holds a BA from Northwestern University and an MA from Columbia University.
MobileDesc: On view at MoMA through Feb 8, Henri Matisse: The Cut-Outs is the most comprehensive exhibition of Matisse’s cut-outs ever mounted. Join curator Samantha Friedman for her unique insights as she discusses Matisse’s invention of this radical new form of art in the last decade of his career.
ShortDesc: On view at MoMA through Feb 8, Henri Matisse: The Cut-Outs is the most comprehensive exhibition of Matisse’s cut-outs ever mounted.
Title: MoMA’s Matisse Cut-Outs

Description:
Nineteen years ago, Geralyn Lucas put on red lipstick before entering the operating room, to show everyone that she planned to come out the bold and daring woman she never thought she could be.

At 27, she didn’t realize how much her single act of courage would connect with women and endear her to breast cancer survivors across the globe. Now she’s back with the same fearless attitude, exploring what it means to survive cancer, only to face new challenges. Join her and writer Delia Ephron for an evening of empowering stories about rediscovering the resilience, courage and humor needed to reinvent yourself at every age.

 

Brief Bios

Geralyn Lucas was 27 when she was diagnosed with breast cancer. Shaking the foundations of her world, she was faced with the harrowing decision of whether or not to undergo a mastectomy. She shared her incredible journey in her memoir, Why I Wore Lipstick: To My Mastectomy, detailing her internal struggle and soul searching to rediscover her “inner cleavage” after losing a key female-defining characteristic and feel sexy and whole once again. Lucas was an editorial producer at ABC News for "20/20" before joining Lifetime Television as a producer and head of the Stop Breast Cancer for Life initiative.

Delia Ephron is a bestselling author and screenwriter. Her movies include The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants, You’ve Got Mail, Hanging Up (based on her novel) and Michael. She has written novels for adults and teenagers, her most recent being The Lion Is In; books of humor, among them How to Eat Like a Child; and essays. Her journalism has appeared regularly in The New York Times, O: The Oprah Magazine, Vogue, More and The Huffington Post. Ephron’s hit play Love, Loss, and What I Wore (co-written with Nora Ephron) ran for more than two years off-Broadway and has been performed in Paris, Rio, Sydney and elsewhere around the world. She lives in New York City.
ShortDesc: Nineteen years ago, Geralyn Lucas put on red lipstick before entering the operating room, to show everyone that she planned to come out the bold and daring woman she never thought she could be.
Title: Then Came Life: Living with Courage, Spirit, and Gratitude after Breast Cancer

Description:
Journey into the exotic world of mah jongg.

Inspired by the museum exhibition Project Mah Jongg, Ann Israel took mah jongg lessons with a group of friends, including Gregg Swain, the co-author of her recent book, Mah Jongg: The Art of the Game. When they started playing, they also began to appreciate the spectacular vintage sets that still existed, and soon Israel purchased her first. As Israel and Swain continued to collect vintage sets, each piece added to their appreciation of the art of the game. Join Israel as she shares images and stories of the most exquisite and rare mah jongg sets and ephemera.
ShortDesc: Journey into the exotic world of mah jongg.
Title: Mah-Jongg: The Art of the Game

Description:
Is alcohol good for my heart? How much is too much? What are the signs of excessive consumption?

Dr. Michael Kluger, MD, MPH, answers your questions and explains the risks and benefits of alcohol at every age: how alcohol impacts your organs—especially the liver and pancreas—and the benefits of moderate consumption on the heart and cardiovascular system.

 

Brief Bio

Michael Kluger, MD, is specialty trained in liver and pancreas surgery, and board certified in general surgery. Dr. Kluger graduated from the New York University School of Medicine, and completed his surgical residency at NYPH-Columbia University Medical Center. He received advanced training in liver transplantation and hepatobiliary surgery at Hospital Henri Mondor in France under the world-renowned surgeon Professor Daniel Cherqui. He is a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, and a member of several prestigious professional organizations, including the Society of Surgical Oncology and the Society for Surgery of the Alimentary Tract. Dr. Kluger focuses on the operative management of pancreatic cancer, liver cancer, gallbladder disease, and metastases to the liver and abdominal peritoneum. These complex diseases require treatment plans individually tailored to the patient’s needs. Dr. Kluger employs a multidisciplinary approach to determine the best-available treatment options that maximize survival and quality of life. He is highly skilled in minimally invasive procedures and uses laparoscopy or robotics whenever indicated. He works collaboratively with patients’ primary care physicians, oncologists, and any other specialists associated with their care and has full access to the specialists and extensive resources of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Columbia University Medical Center.
ShortDesc: Is alcohol good for my heart? How much is too much? What are the signs of excessive consumption?
Title: I Like to Have a Drink, So What?

Description:
At 80 million strong, Generation-Y millennials are beginning to move into leadership positions in corporations, government and their own businesses.

Join Lindsey Pollack, the nation’s number-one Google-ranked “Gen-Y career expert” and author of the Becoming the Boss, and Dan Coates, president and co-founder of Ypulse, the leading authority on millennials, for an insightful discussion about how to navigate this enormous demographic shift—whether you’re a millennial on the rise or you work with one!

 

Brief Bios

Lindsey Pollak is a keynote speaker, corporate consultant and one of the country's leading experts on the Millennial Generation. She currently serves as an official Ambassador for LinkedIn, Spokesperson for The Hartford's "My Tomorrow" campaign and Chair of Cosmopolitan magazine's Millennial Advisory Board. Her speaking and consulting clients have included Barclays, Citi, GE, PwC, Ralph Lauren, Time Inc., Verizon, Yale, Harvard, Princeton, MIT and over 150 other organizations. Lindsey's advice and opinions have been featured in such media outlets as "The Today Show," The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, CNN and NPR. Forbes named her blog one of the 100 Best Websites for Your Career. Lindsey is a graduate of Yale University and is based in New York City.

Dan Coates is president and co-founder of Ypulse, the leading authority on Millennials. Ypulse’s intelligence is derived from SurveyU.com, an online research community of more than 150,000 Millennials and Thumb, a mobile social Q&A network where two million Millennials go to ask and answer each other’s questions. Ypulse leverages these tools to help those who market to and work with youth—and who wish to reach them in an authentic manner.

 

This event is part of the Young Professionals series.
ShortDesc: At 80 million strong, Generation-Y millennials are beginning to move into leadership positions in corporations, government and their own businesses.
Title: Becoming the Boss: New Rules for the Next Generation of Leaders

Description:
Traveling in Europe in August 1938, David Kurtz, the author’s grandfather, captured three minutes of ordinary life in a small, predominantly Jewish town in Poland on 16 mm film.

More than 70 years later, through the brutal twists of history, these few minutes of home-movie footage would become a memorial to an entire community—an entire culture—that was annihilated in the Holocaust. Join Glenn Kurtz, author of Three Minutes in Poland, as he shares his four-year journey to identify those captured in the film.
ShortDesc: Traveling in Europe in August 1938, David Kurtz, the author’s grandfather, captured three minutes of ordinary life in a small, predominantly Jewish town in Poland on 16 mm film.
Title: Three Minutes in Poland: Discovering a Lost World in a 1938 Family Film

Description:
Why does eating chocolate make you feel so angry?

Is your aluminum cookware hurting you? Can tryptophan supplements improve your mood? How do fruits and vegetables protect us from aging? Why does our brain make us crave fat, salt and sugar? Join Gary Wenk, PhD, professor of psychology and neuroscience at Ohio State, to understand how everything you consume can affect how you think, feel and act.

 

Brief Bio

Gary L. Wenk, PhD, is a Professor of Psychology and Neuroscience and Molecular Virology, Immunology and Medical Genetics at the Ohio State University.
MobileDesc: Why does eating chocolate make you feel so angry? Is your aluminum cookware hurting you? Can tryptophan supplements improve your mood? How do fruits and vegetables protect us from aging? Why does our brain make us crave fat, salt and sugar? Join Gary Wenk, PhD, professor of psychology and neuroscience at Ohio State, to understand how everything you consume can affect how you think, feel and act.
ShortDesc: Join Gary Wenk, PhD, professor of psychology and neuroscience at Ohio State, to understand how everything you consume can affect how you think, feel and act.
Title: Food and the Brain

Description:
Everybody knows and loves the American Songbook, but it’s less widely understood why this stream of great songs dried up around 1950.

Gershwin, Porter and Berlin were replaced with “Come On-a My House” and “How Much Is that Doggie in the Window?” and a few years later, Elvis and rock ’n’ roll arrived. Join acclaimed cultural historian Ben Yagoda as he draws on previously untapped archival sources and scores of interviews to illuminate broad musical trends through a series of intertwined stories.
ShortDesc: Everybody knows and loves the American Songbook, but it’s less widely understood why this stream of great songs dried up around 1950.
Title: The Death of Tin Pan Alley and the Rebirth of the Great American Song

Description:

Description:
Join a panel of inspiring women as they share the moments that mattered—from their career highs and lows to their ever-challenging work-life balance; from the times when they first realized success was possible to times when they knew they had to shift their personal lives to accomplish their goals; from overwhelming craziness to lessons learned, to great advice they’ve received along the way.

Description:
Throughout history, American Jews have persistently viewed Abraham Lincoln as one of their own, casting him as a Jewish sojourner and role model.

Join Gary Phillip Zola, author of We Called Him Rabbi Abraham, in conversation with Brandeis University’s Jonathan Sarna, author of a forthcoming book on Lincoln and the Jews, for a fascinating chronicle of American Jewry’s unfolding historical encounter with the life and symbolic image of Abraham Lincoln.

 

Brief Bios

Gary Phillip Zola is the executive director of the Jacob Rader Marcus Center of the American Jewish Archives and professor of the American Jewish experience at Hebrew Union College–Jewish Institute of Religion in Cincinnati.

Jonathan D. Sarna is the Joseph H. & Belle R. Braun Professor of American Jewish History at Brandeis University and is generally regarded as one of the most prominent historians of American Jewish history, religion and life.

 

This event is in partnership with the Museum of Jewish Heritage and takes place in the museum’s Edmond J. Safra Hall, 36 Battery Place, NYC.
MobileDesc: Throughout history, American Jews have persistently viewed Abraham Lincoln as one of their own, casting him as a Jewish sojourner and role model. Join Gary Phillip Zola, author of We Called Him Rabbi Abraham, in conversation with Brandeis University’s Jonathan Sarna, author of a forthcoming book on Lincoln and the Jews, for a fascinating chronicle of American Jewry’s unfolding historical encounter with the life and symbolic image of Abraham Lincoln.
ShortDesc: Throughout history, American Jews have persistently viewed Abraham Lincoln as one of their own, casting him as a Jewish sojourner and role model.
Title: Lincoln and the Jews

Description:
Good communicators are like healthy eaters.

We all know that consuming fewer calories each day can lead to a healthier life, but did you know that using fewer words makes you more productive? By simplifying the way we communicate, we can shorten meetings, reduce email and reclaim precious downtime in our overscheduled days. Emmy® Award-winning correspondent and communication coach Bill McGowan shares strategies for getting your message across with pitch-perfect communication.

 

Brief Bio

Bill McGowan is the coach of some of the biggest names in business and entertainment, including Sheryl Sandberg, Eli Manning, Kelly Clarkson, Jack Welch, Thomas Keller and Kenneth Cole, and is a trusted advisor in the C-suites of companies like Facebook, Deutsche Bank, Campbell’s Soup, L'Oreal and Burberry.

 

This event is part of the Young Professionals series.

Emmy® Award-winning correspondent and communication coach Bill McGowan shares strategies for getting your message across with pitch-perfect communication.

Title: Pitch-Perfect Communication

Description:
Everything began to unravel on October 5, 1986, when a Nicaraguan soldier downed an American plane carrying arms to Contra guerrillas.

Washington’s clandestine program of selling arms to Iran and giving the profits to the Contras, in exchange for help freeing hostages in Beirut was exposed. Join author Malcolm Byrne as he revisits and shares his research into this largely forgotten and misrepresented episode.

 

Brief Bio

Malcolm Byrne, Deputy Director and Director of Research, has worked at the National Security Archive since 1986, and since 1990 has supervised the research process of identifying and obtaining documentation for the Archive's collections. He currently directs the Openness in Russia and Eastern Europe Project, and the U.S.-Iran Relations Project, both of which promote multinational and multi-archival approaches to the study of recent, controversial historical events. Previously, he served as co-director of the Iran-contra documentation project, and coordinated the Archive's project on U.S.-Soviet relations during the Cold War.
MobileDesc: Everything began to unravel on October 5, 1986, when a Nicaraguan soldier downed an American plane carrying arms to Contra guerrillas. Washington’s clandestine program of selling arms to Iran and giving the profits to the Contras, in exchange for help freeing hostages in Beirut was exposed. Join author Malcolm Byrne as he revisits and shares his research into this largely forgotten and misrepresented episode.
ShortDesc: Everything began to unravel on October 5, 1986, when a Nicaraguan soldier downed an American plane carrying arms to Contra guerrillas.
Title: The Iran-Contra Scandal Revisited

Description:
James Andrew Miller Photo Credit: Victoria Wills

Hear the inside story of how the game of Monopoly came into existence, the heavy embellishment of its provenance by Parker Brothers and multiple media outlets, the lost female originator of the game, and one man’s lifelong obsession to tell the true story about the game’s questionable origins, from The Monopolists author Mary Pilon, as she also illuminates the cutthroat nature of American business over the last century.

 

Brief Bios

Mary Pilon is an award-winning sports reporter at The New York Times. She was previously a staff reporter at the Wall Street Journal for the paper’s Money and Investing section. In 2011, she was named one of Forbes magazine’s 30 Under 30 for media. Her work has appeared at Gawker, USA Today and New York magazine and she is an honors graduate of New York University.

James Andrew Miller is an award-winning journalist and #1 New York Times bestselling author. He got his start as a member of the Television Reporting Team at The Washington Post before becoming Special Assistant and Chief Speechwriter to then Senate Majority Leader Howard Baker. He was Vice President of Television for Norman Lear’s ACT III Communications, Executive Vice President of Original Programming for USA Network, producer with CBS News and Senior Executive Producer of "Anderson Cooper 360" & "Paula Zahn Now" at CNN. He is the author of Running In Place: Inside the Senate and co-author of Live From New York: An Uncensored History Of Saturday Night Live and Those Guys Have All The Fun: Inside the World of ESPN. He has written for The Washington Post, The New York Times, Newsweek, Grantland, The Daily Beast, Salon, The Harvard Journal on Legislation and others.
MobileDesc: Hear the inside story of how the game of Monopoly came into existence, the heavy embellishment of its provenance by Parker Brothers and multiple media outlets, the lost female originator of the game, and one man’s lifelong obsession to tell the true story about the game’s questionable origins, from The Monopolists author Mary Pilon, as she also illuminates the cutthroat nature of American business over the last century.
ShortDesc: Hear the inside story of how the game of Monopoly came into existence.
Title: The Monopolists: Obsession, Fury and the Scandal Behind America’s Favorite Board Game

Description:
Dorothy Fields Photo Courtesy of David Lahm

Dorothy Fields wrote over 400 songs for Broadway musicals and film, including some of the most enduring lyrics of the golden age of American popular songs.

Enjoy listening to favorites like “I Can’t Give You Anything but Love,” and “The Way You Look Tonight” and learn about her early challenges as a woman songwriter, her show-business family, her partnership with Jerome Kern and more about her life and work from her son, David Lahm.

 

Brief Bios

Harvey Granat is a popular cabaret performer, Broadway producer and a historian/educator of the American popular song.

David Lahm, the son of Dorothy Fields, is an accomplished jazz pianist and arranger.
MobileDesc: Dorothy Fields wrote over 400 songs for Broadway musicals and film, including some of the most enduring lyrics of the golden age of American popular songs. Enjoy listening to favorites like “I Can’t Give You Anything but Love,” and “The Way You Look Tonight” and learn about her early challenges as a woman songwriter, her show-business family, her partnership with Jerome Kern and more about her life and work from her son, David Lahm.
ShortDesc: Dorothy Fields wrote over 400 songs for Broadway musicals and film, including some of the most enduring lyrics of the golden age of American popular songs.
Title: The Lyrics and Life of Dorothy Fields

Description:
Rita Hayworth is a true legend of the golden days of Hollywood.

With plenty of film clips to remind us why she’s immortal, Marc Courtade explores her beginnings as a child performer in vaudeville, her work with Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly in film, her pin-up status among GI’s in World War II and how Gilda made her a cultural icon.
MobileDesc: Rita Hayworth is a true legend of the golden days of Hollywood. With plenty of film clips to remind us why she’s immortal, Marc Courtade explores her beginnings as a child performer in vaudeville, her work with Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly in film, her pin-up status among GI’s in World War II and how Gilda made her a cultural icon.
ShortDesc: Rita Hayworth is a true legend of the golden days of Hollywood.
Title: Great Entertainers with Marc Courtade: Rita Hayworth—Screen Goddess

Description:
As John Rando’s breathtaking new production of On the Town arrives on Broadway at the Lyric Theatre this season, take a moment to delve into the music, the dance and the context of this great musical comedy.

The hugely successful 1944 premieres of the musical comedy On the Town and the ballet Fancy Free, marked the sudden, unexpected arrival of two major new talents on the New York theatrical scene, Leonard Bernstein and Jerome Robbins, and the beginning of their extraordinary 30-year collaboration.

 

Brief Bio

Louis Rosen is a songwriter, guitarist, author, teacher and 2005 Guggenheim Foundation Fellow in Music Composition. Louis recently completed his thirtieth year of teaching the music theory and appreciation curriculum for the 92nd Street Y School of Music.
MobileDesc: As John Rando’s breathtaking new production of On the Town arrives on Broadway at the Lyric Theatre this season, take a moment to delve into the music, the dance and the context of this great musical comedy. The hugely successful 1944 premieres of the musical comedy On the Town and the ballet Fancy Free, marked the sudden, unexpected arrival of two major new talents on the New York theatrical scene, Leonard Bernstein and Jerome Robbins, and the beginning of their extraordinary 30-year collaboration.
ShortDesc: As John Rando’s breathtaking new production of On the Town arrives on Broadway at the Lyric Theatre this season, take a moment to delve into the music, the dance and the context of this great musical comedy.
Title: Behind the Music with Louis Rosen: Leonard Bernstein and Jerome Robbins—On the Town and Fancy Free

Description:
Leonardo da Vinci—artist, scientist, anatomist, architect, engineer, inventor and more—was the quintessential and original Renaissance man.

That our fascination with him has never faded is a testament to his genius. Join Dr. Gail Saltz in conversation with art historian Robert Simon, whose involvement in the discovery of da Vinci’s lost painting, Salvator Mundi, was the culmination of a life-long study of the artist.

 

Brief Bios

Dr. Gail Saltz is Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry at The New York Presbyterian Hospital, psychoanalyst with The New York Psychoanalytic Institute, columnist, bestselling author and television commentator including frequent contributing to the "Today Show," CNN and MSNBC. She is the emotional wellness contributor to Health Magazine and Health.com, Chair the of 92Y 7 Days of Genius Advisory Committee and Consultant and Event Moderator for the Clinton Foundation’s Health Matters Initiative.

Robert Simon is an art historian and private art dealer in New York, specializing in Italian Renaissance and Baroque paintings.

 

This event is part of the Psychobiography with Gail Saltz series.

This lecture is underwritten by Nancy and Paul G. Levy.
MobileDesc: Leonardo da Vinci—artist, scientist, anatomist, architect, engineer, inventor and more—was the quintessential and original Renaissance man. That our fascination with him has never faded is a testament to his genius. Join Dr. Gail Saltz in conversation with art historian Robert Simon, whose involvement in the discovery of da Vinci’s lost painting, Salvator Mundi, was the culmination of a life-long study of the artist.
ShortDesc: Leonardo da Vinci—artist, scientist, anatomist, architect, engineer, inventor and more—was the quintessential and original Renaissance man.
Title: Psychobiography with Dr. Gail Saltz: On the Genius of Leonardo da Vinci with Robert Simon

Description:
American courts routinely hand down harsh sentences to individuals, but a very different standard of justice applies to corporations.

Drawing on detailed data from more than a decade of federal cases, author Brandon Garrett takes readers into a complex, compromised world of prosecutors’ deals with corporations. He explains why so few individuals have been accountable for corporate crimes, why eye-catching fines may not result in meaningful changes in companies—and why certain key reforms would result in more meaningful prosecution of corporate crime.

 

Brief Bio

Brandon L. Garrett teaches at the University of Virginia School of Law, where he has been a professor since 2005. His research on our criminal justice system has ranged from the lessons to be learned from cases where innocent people were exonerated by DNA tests, to research on false confessions, forensics and eyewitness memory, to the difficult compromises that prosecutors reach when targeting the largest corporations in the world. His 2011 book, Convicting the Innocent: Where Criminal Prosecutions Go Wrong, examining the cases of the first 250 people to be exonerated by DNA testing, has been translated in Japan and Taiwan, and is being translated in China.
MobileDesc: American courts routinely hand down harsh sentences to individuals, but a very different standard of justice applies to corporations. Drawing on detailed data from more than a decade of federal cases, author Brandon Garrett takes readers into a complex, compromised world of prosecutors’ deals with corporations. He explains why so few individuals have been accountable for corporate crimes, why eye-catching fines may not result in meaningful changes in companies—and why certain key reforms would result in more meaningful prosecution of corporate crime.
ShortDesc: American courts routinely hand down harsh sentences to individuals, but a very different standard of justice applies to corporations.
Title: Too Big to Jail

Description:
Join Padma Lakshmi, Emmy®-award winning host of "Top Chef," as she shares her decades-long struggle with endometriosis and the misdiagnoses and unsuccessful treatments that have led her to champion this cause.

Her visionary surgeon and co-founder of the Endometriosis Foundation of America, Dr. Tamer Seckin, addresses the disease’s acute and chronic symptoms, treatment options, and a new research project seeking to find its genetic signature.

 

Brief Bios

Padma Lakshmi is an internationally known actress, food expert, entrepreneur, model and award-winning author. She recently wrapped filming her eleventh season as host of Bravo’s Emmy award winning “Top Chef.” In 2009, Lakshmi co-founded the Endometriosis Foundation of America with Tamer Seckin, MD, spreading awareness and garnering funding for research and teen health education. She has been recognized by the New York State senate for her efforts in women's health and also helped to launch the first research center in the US for gynopathology at MIT.

Tamer Seckin, MD, is a Board Certified gynecologist and internationally renowned specialist in minimally invasive laparoscopic surgery. He is in private practice in New York City with more than 30 years of experience. Dr. Seckin is the co-founder and medical director of the Endometriosis Foundation of America, and has dedicated his life to the understanding and treatment of this little-known disease. He is a recipient of the prestigious 2012 Ellis Island Medal of Honor, which pays homage to the immigrant experience and highlights the contributions made to America by those who have immigrated here.

Her visionary surgeon and co-founder of the Endometriosis Foundation of America, Dr. Tamer Seckin, addresses the disease’s acute and chronic symptoms, treatment options, and a new research project seeking to find its genetic signature.

Title: Killer Cramps Are Not Normal: All About Endometriosis

Description:
Michael Cerveris exploded onto the Broadway scene in 1993 as the fantastic pinball wizard in The Who's Tommy.

He won a Tony for his role in Sondheim’s Assassins, has been captain of the Titanic and did a wild stint downtown in Hedwig and the Angry Inch. Join him in discussion with playwright and critic Tony Vellela to learn more about Michael’s remarkable career; how he balances his energies to excel as an actor, singer and guitarist; and his particular expertise with Stephen Sondheim’s work.

 

Can't make it to the event? Leave your questions for our guests below, and they might be used on stage during the Q&A. Keep an eye on 92Y On Demand after the event for any video clips we might share! You might see your question used on stage.

Description:
Laura Lippman Photo Credit: Jan Cobb

Laura Lippman was a reporter for 20 years, including 12 at The Baltimore Sun.

She began writing novels while working full-time and published seven books about “accidental PI” Tess Monaghan before leaving daily journalism in 2001. Her work has been the recipient of Edgar®, Anthony, Agatha, Shamus, Nero Wolfe, Gumshoe and Barry Awards. She also has been nominated for other prizes in the crime fiction field, including the Hammett and the Macavity. She was the first-ever winner of the Mayor’s Prize for Literary Excellence and the first genre writer recognized as author of the year by the Maryland Library Association.

Description:
Photo courtesy New Museum, 2006

MoMA’s Forever Now (December 14, 2014-April 5, 2015) presents the work of 17 artists whose paintings reflect a singular approach that characterizes our cultural moment at the beginning of this new millennium: they refuse to allow us to define or even meter our time by them.

Join Laura Hoptman, curator of contemporary art in the department of painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art, for an inside look into this exhibition and her curatorial process.

Description:
Enjoy live music, singing, and an enlightening exploration of the stories behind the music of Jerry Bock (Fiddler on the Roof, Fiorello!) and Jerry Herman (Hello Dolly, Mame, La Cage aux Folles).

 

Brief Bios

Carla Innerfield is a musicologist, music educator and performer.

Chris Coogan is a jazz and gospel musician who has been called “masterful” by The New York Times.

Description:
Colon cancer remains the second leading cause of cancer-related death in the US, even though it is largely preventable and highly curable with early detection.

This lecture will help you understand what colon cancer screening entails, both in terms of the process and what it means for one’s greater well-being.

 

Brief Bio

A leading clinician and researcher in gastrointestinal cancers, Dr. Felice Schnoll-Sussman is the Director of the Jay Monahan Center for Gastrointestinal Health at New-York Presbyterian Hospital/ Weill Cornell Medical Center. Dr. Schnoll-Sussman had been serving as the Center’s Director since 2013 and as its Director of Research since 2007. An Associate Professor of Clinical Medicine in the Division of Gastroenterology and Hepatology, Dr. Schnoll-Sussman is the Medical Director of the Esophageal Program, former president of the New York Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy, the co-director of the New York City Colon Cancer Control Coalition and an active committee member of several national gastroenterology societies, including the American College of Gastroenterology (of which she serves as Manhattan governor), American Gastroenterological Association and the American Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy. She has also been the recipient of several awards, including the American Cancer Society’s “Mother of the Year Award,” American College of Gastroenterology/Salix Leadership Award, New York Society of Gastrointestinal Endoscopy Florence Lefcourt Research Award, American College of Gastroenterology Governor Service Award, Michael’s Mission Service Award, Linda Horowitz Cancer Research Foundation Clinical Scholar Award and the New York Society for Gastrointestinal Endoscopy David Falkenstein Award. After receiving her MD from Mount Sinai School of Medicine, Dr. Schnoll-Sussman completed residency training in internal medicine at NYU School of Medicine, where she served as chief resident, followed by a fellowship in gastroenterology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.
MobileDesc: Colon cancer remains the second leading cause of cancer-related death in the US, even though it is largely preventable and highly curable with early detection. This lecture will help you understand what colon cancer screening entails, both in terms of the process and what it means for one’s greater well-being. Dr. Felice Schnoll-Sussman is the director of the Jay Monahan Center for Gastrointestinal Health and an associate attending at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center.
ShortDesc: Colon cancer remains the second leading cause of cancer-related death in the US, even though it is largely preventable and highly curable with early detection.
Title: Colon Cancer: The More You Know

Description:
Leah Koenig’s philosophy when it comes to traditional cooking is simple: history is important but should not stand in the way of creativity or innovation.

Join her as she shares recipes from her new book, Modern Jewish Cooking, which brings the tastiest Jewish dishes, both Old World and New, to today’s seasonal kitchen.

 

This event is in partnership with the Museum of Jewish Heritage and takes place in the museum’s Edmond J. Safra Hall, 36 Battery Place, NYC.

Title: The Modern Jewish Cookbook

Description:
Join beloved "Murphy Brown" star Candice Bergen as she recounts with wit and charisma the stories of her career, love and motherhood.

In her new memoir A Fine Romance, five time Emmy award, two Golden Globe winning and Oscar-nominated actress shares stories from her extraordinary life: her marriage to acclaimed French director Louis Malle, the birth of daughter Chloe, her hit show "Murphy Brown" and being pulled into the 1992 presidential campaign by Dan Quayle, widowhood, falling in love again and watching her daughter blossom. She is like the honest best friend everyone wants by the fireside.

A Fine Romance begins with Bergen’s charming first husband, French director Louis Malle, whose huge appetite for life broadened her horizons and whose occasional darkness never diminished their love for each other. But her real romance begins when she discovers overpowering love for her daughter Chloe after years of ambivalence about motherhood. As Chloe grows up, Bergen finds her comic genius in the biggest TV role of the 80s, "Murphy Brown." Fifteen years into their marriage, Malle is diagnosed with cancer, and Candice is unflinching in describing her and Chloe’s despair over his death. But after years of widowhood, she feels the sweet shock of finding a different kind of soulmate. Candice takes us through the first years of her new marriage and shares the bittersweetness of watching Chloe leave home and flourish. Always an exquisite beauty, she also shares the comedy of finally losing a battle against those damn wrinkles and extra pounds.

 

Can't make it to the event? Leave your questions for our guests below, and they might be used on stage during the Q&A. Keep an eye on 92Y On Demand after the event for any video clips we might share! You might see your question used on stage.

 
 

Brief Bio

Candice Bergen’s film credits include The Sand Pebbles, Carnal Knowledge, Starting Over (for which she received an Oscar nomination) and Miss Congeniality. On television, she made headlines as the tough-talking broadcast journalist and star of "Murphy Brown." She later starred with James Spader and William Shatner in the critically acclaimed series "Boston Legal."

Description:
Linda Fairstein Photo Credit: Peter Simon

Linda Fairstein, former Sex Crimes Unit bureau chief in the Manhattan District Attorney’s Office for almost three decades, is one of America's foremost legal experts on sexual assault and domestic violence.

In 1996, her first crime novel, Final Jeopardy, introduced prosecutor Alexandra Cooper and NYPD homicide detective Mike Chapman. The 16th novel in the series, Terminal City, was published in 2014 and was Fairstein’s 13th straight New York Times bestseller. She has won the Nero Wolfe Award for best crime novel and International Thriller Writers’ Silver Bullet Award.

Description:
Fresh off his Tony Awards® for The Bridges of Madison County, superstar composer-lyricist Jason Robert Brown is back with a new, Sin City-set Broadway musical, Honeymoon in Vegas—a smash last year at Paper Mill Playhouse.


Featuring screen star Tony Danza and Tony nominee Rob McClure (Chaplin), the glitzy show boasts Brown’s “revelation of a score” (The New York Times) and a hilarious book by Andrew Bergman, writer of the cult-classic 1992 movie. Enjoy performances and hear from the cast and creatives about this razzle-dazzle tale of love, gambling — and skydiving Elvises.

Description:
Photo Credit: From Young Man with a Horn courtesy of Hoagy Bix Carmichael

Hoagy Carmichael wrote with some of the greatest lyricists and went on to become a movie star.

Enjoy listening to “Stardust,” “Georgia on My Mind,” “The Nearness of You,” “Two Sleepy People,” “Skylark,” “Lazy River,” and his Academy-Award® winning “In the Cool, Cool, Cool of the Evening,” while hearing stories about his life and work from his son Hoagy Bix Carmichael.

 

Brief Bios

Harvey Granat is a popular cabaret performer, Broadway producer and a historian/educator of the American popular song.

Description:
Everyone has taken antibiotics at some point, but what is the long-term impact of our reliance on them?

Join Dr. Martin Blaser, one of the world’s foremost experts on infectious disease and the human microbiome, for a discussion on his pioneering research and what it reveals about the impact of our overuse of antibiotics, including the rise of obesity, asthma, diabetes and certain forms of cancer.

 

Brief Bio

Dr. Martin Blaser has studied the role of bacteria in human disease for more than thirty years and is the director of the Human Microbiome Program at NYU.
MobileDesc: Everyone has taken antibiotics at some point, but what is the long-term impact of our reliance on them? Join Dr. Martin Blaser, one of the world’s foremost experts on infectious disease and the human microbiome, for a discussion on his pioneering research and what it reveals about the impact of our overuse of antibiotics, including the rise of obesity, asthma, diabetes and certain forms of cancer.
ShortDesc: Everyone has taken antibiotics at some point, but what is the long-term impact of our reliance on them?
Title: Missing Microbes: The Impact of Antibiotics

Description:
By the year 2050, policymakers, farmers and scientists will face one of the most pressing environmental challenges threatening the planet—feeding nine billion people.

The increasing demand for food is the largest driver of climate change, biodiversity loss and environmental destruction. To meet the world's future food-security and sustainability needs, food availability must grow substantially and agriculture’s environmental footprint must shrink dramatically.

Dr. Jonathan Foley, executive director of the California Academy of Sciences and chief architect of a plan that takes a deeper look at agriculture, explains opportunities to deliver more nutrition to the world while reducing waste, improving efficiency and sustaining the world’s ecosystems and freshwater resources.

 

Brief Bio

Dr. Jonathan Foley is the Executive Director of the California Academy of Sciences. A global environmental scientist, he led major research institutes at the University of Minnesota and the University of Wisconsin. A frequent advisor to governments, foundations, NGOs and corporations, Foley has won numerous awards, including the Heinz Prize for the Environment and the Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers.

Description:
Photo Credit: Deborah R. Gerhardt

Join constitutional scholar and leading legal expert Michael Gerhardt as he tells the stories of thirteen presidents who linger in memory mainly as punch lines and whom scholars think had no constitutional impact.

From Martin Van Buren to Franklin Pierce to Jimmy Carter, Gerhardt separates these presidents’ political failures from their constitutional impact and reveals how they defied popular opinion to take strong stands.

 

Brief Bio

Michael Gerhardt is Samuel Ashe Distinguished Professor of Constitutional Law at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. A nationally recognized authority on constitutional conflicts, he has testified in several Supreme Court confirmation hearings, and has published five books, including The Power of Precedent.

Title: The Forgotten Presidents and Their Constitutional Legacy

Description:
Lee Child Photo Credit: Sigrid Estrada

Lee Child is the #1 internationally bestselling author of the Jack Reacher thrillers.

His debut, Killing Floor, won both the Anthony and the Barry Awards for best first mystery, and The Enemy won both the Barry and the Nero Awards for best novel. Jack Reacher, the film based on the ninth novel, One Shot, stars Tom Cruise and Robert Duvall. Prior to his writing career, Child worked as a presentation director for Granada Television during British TV’s golden age. During his tenure his company made Brideshead Revisited, The Jewel in the Crown, Prime Suspect and Cracker.

Description:
Cesar Chavez began as a migrant worker, founded a labor union, launched a movement, inspired a generation and became one of the great leaders of the 20th-century.

Join biographer Miriam Pawel for a deeper look into the life of a visionary whose eyes were fixed on a horizon others often could not see, a brilliant strategist who sometimes stumbled and a streetwise organizer whose pragmatism was often at odds with his soaring dreams. Pawel shares her research into the documents, audiotapes and interviews she reviewed as she traces the dramatic rise and devolution of Chavez’s iconic life.

 

Brief Bio

Miriam Pawel is the author of The Union of Their Dreams, widely acclaimed as the most nuanced history of Cesar Chavez’s movement. She is a Pulitzer-winning editor who spent twenty-five years working for Newsday and the Los Angeles Times. She was recently awarded a National Endowment for the Humanities fellowship, and lives in Southern California.

Description:
New York City is a noisy place, but is it affecting our health and well-being?

Our daily use of MP3 players, exposure to mass transit, noisy restaurants and the constant buzz of the city streets add to the cacophony we have all acclimated to. Get the facts on how the sounds of the city may be negatively affecting your psychological and physical health.

 

Brief Bio

Dr. Craig Kasper is the Chief Audiology Officer of New York Hearing Doctors. Recognized as one of the Future Leaders of Audiology by his colleagues and the American Academy of Audiology, Dr. Kasper has been at the front lines of public education and hearing healthcare service for over 17 years. He completed his Doctorate of Audiology at the University of Florida and earned his master’s degree with clinical honors from the State University of New York at Buffalo. Dr. Kasper is a Fellow of the American Academy of Audiology (AAA), holds the Certificate of Clinical Competence from the American Speech-Language and Hearing Association (ASHA), and is a member of the National Hearing Conservation Association (NHCA) and the New York State Speech-Language Hearing Association (NYSSLHA).
MobileDesc: New York City is a noisy place, but is it affecting our health and well-being? Our daily use of MP3 players, exposure to mass transit, noisy restaurants and the constant buzz of the city streets add to the cacophony we have all acclimated to. Get the facts on how the sounds of the city may be negatively affecting your psychological and physical health.
ShortDesc: New York City is a noisy place, but is it affecting our health and well-being?
Title: Noise Wars: A New Yorker’s Guide to Sound in the City

Description:
Considered by many the greatest film actor of his generation, Spencer Tracy had this approach to acting: “Learn your lines and don't bump into the furniture.”

With 78 films to his credit from 1930 through 1967, he received nine Academy Award® nominations and won twice. Join Marc Courtade for a look at his life and work and remember why he is still regarded as one of Hollywood’s finest performers.

Description:
Candide, the satirical operetta based on the novella by Voltaire, with music by Leonard Bernstein, book by Lillian Hellman and lyrics by Richard Wilbur and John La Touche, premiered in 1956 and closed after 78 performances—Bernstein’s first theatrical failure.

Yet over time, and eventually with a new libretto by Hugh Wheeler and additional lyrics by Stephen Sondheim, the work has achieved enormous popularity with both audiences and critics alike. Come explore the evolution of one of the finest scores in the history of musical theater.

 

Brief Bio

Louis Rosen is a songwriter, guitarist, author, teacher and 2005 Guggenheim Foundation Fellow in Music Composition. Louis recently completed his thirtieth year of teaching the music theory and appreciation curriculum for the 92nd Street Y School of Music.
MobileDesc: Candide, the satirical operetta based on the novella by Voltaire, with music by Leonard Bernstein, book by Lillian Hellman and lyrics by Richard Wilbur and John La Touche, premiered in 1956 and closed after 78 performances—Bernstein’s first theatrical failure. Yet over time, and eventually with a new libretto by Hugh Wheeler and additional lyrics by Stephen Sondheim, the work has achieved enormous popularity with both audiences and critics alike. Come explore the evolution of one of the finest scores in the history of musical theater.

Title: Behind the Music with Louis Rosen: Bernstein’s Candide

Description:
Moody, mystical and enchanting, Coney Island has thrilled newcomers and soothed native New Yorkers for decades with its kaleidoscopic panorama of people, places and events.

Journey into the stunning gallery of Coney Island portraits created by the world’s finest poets, essayists and fiction writers, including Walt Whitman, Stephen Crane, Federico García Lorca, Isaac Bashevis Singer and E. E. Cummings.

 

Brief Bios

Louis J. Parascandola is professor of English at Long Island University. He is the editor of "Look for Me All Around You": Anglophone Caribbean Immigrants in the Harlem Renaissance and coeditor of In Search of Asylum: The Later Writings of Eric Walrond.

John Parascandola taught at the University of Wisconsin-Madison before serving as chief of the History of Medicine Division of the National Library of Medicine and as Public Health Service Historian. He is the author of The Development of American Pharmacology: John J. Abel and the Shaping of a Discipline and Sex, Sin, and Science: A History of Syphilis in America.

Description:
Harlan Coben Photo Credit: Claudio Marinesco

With over 60 million copies of his books in print worldwide, Harlan Coben has most recently written seven consecutive novels—Missing You, Six Years, Stay Close, Live Wire, Caught, Long Lost and Hold Tight—which all debuted at #1 on the New York Times bestseller list and lists around the world.

He has won the Edgar Award, the Shamus Award and the Anthony Award—the first author to win all three—and his critically acclaimed novels have been called “ingenious” (The New York Times), “poignant and insightful” (Los Angeles Times), “consistently entertaining” (Houston Chronicle), “superb” (Chicago Tribune) and “must reading” (Philadelphia Inquirer).

Description:
The fear of aging has a cascading domino effect.

But the good news is there is abundant research showing that, contrary to popular belief, our sense of well-being often increases during later midlife and older age. Join Mindy Greenstein, a 51-year-old psychologist, and Jimmie Holland, an 86-year-old psychiatrist to explore the ways in which life gets “lighter as we go.”

Free to Himan Brown Senior Program Members.

 

Brief Bios

Mindy Greenstein, PhD, is Clinical Psychologist and Psycho-oncologist, Writer and National Speaker, and Consultant to the geriatric psychiatry group in the Department of Psychiatry & Behavioral Sciences at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

Jimmie Holland, MD, is Wayne E. Chapman Chair in Psychiatric Oncology, Attending Psychiatrist, and Founder of the geriatric psychiatry group at the Department of Psychiatry & Behavioral Sciences at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and Professor of Psychiatry at Weill Medical School of Cornell University.

Description:
Kelly Turner, a researcher and lecturer in integrative oncology, was the first to delve deeply into studying “radical remission” from cancer—that is, when someone recovers from cancer without the help of conventional medicine, or after conventional medicine has failed.

Join her as she describes the nine most common healing factors that emerged from her research and shares more from her New York Times bestseller, Radical Remission: Surviving Cancer Against All Odds.

 

Brief Bio

Kelly Turner, PhD, is a researcher, author and lecturer in the field of integrative oncology and the founder of the Radical Remission Project. Her specialized research focus is the Radical Remission of cancer, which is a remission that occurs either in the absence of Western medicine, or after Western medicine has failed to achieve remission. Dr. Turner’s interest in complementary medicine began when she received her B.A. from Harvard University, and it later became the sole focus of her Ph.D. at the University of California, Berkeley. Her dissertation research included a year-long trip around the world, for which she traveled to 10 countries to interview 50 alternative healers and 20 Radical Remission cancer survivors about their healing techniques. Since then, her ongoing research has led her to interview more than 100 survivors and analyze over 1,000 cases of radical remission, and to found “The Radical Remission Project,” an innovative website dedicated both to collecting new cases of Radical Remission for research purposes, and to connecting Radical Remission survivors with current cancer patients.
MobileDesc: Kelly Turner, a researcher and lecturer in integrative oncology, was the first to delve deeply into studying “radical remission” from cancer—that is, when someone recovers from cancer without the help of conventional medicine, or after conventional medicine has failed. Join her as she describes the nine most common healing factors that emerged from her research and shares more from her New York Times bestseller, Radical Remission: Surviving Cancer Against All Odds.
ShortDesc: Kelly Turner, a researcher and lecturer in integrative oncology, was the first to delve deeply into studying “radical remission” from cancer—that is, when someone recovers from cancer without the help of conventional medicine, or after conventional medicine has failed.
Title: Radical Remission

Over the course of four years William Helmreich walked more than 6,000 miles of New York City streets, thoroughly exploring all five boroughs and accumulating a wealth of stories about the people he met and places he found along the way.

Join Helmreich as he shares what he learned about the heart and soul of New York, from its most over-looked and hidden corners to the diversity and determination of the people who have made this city home.

Description:
Nachman Libeskind’s incredible story is an odyssey through crucial events of the 20th century and a testament to resilience, optimism and survival.

Join his daughter, Annette Libeskind Berkovits, author of In the Unlikeliest of Places, and his son, architect Daniel Libeskind, as they tell of how this remarkable Polish Jew narrowly escaped two murderous totalitarian systems to immigrate to Israel and ultimately New York City, where he built a new life as a Modernist painter.

 

This event is in partnership with the Museum of Jewish Heritage and takes place in the museum’s Edmond J. Safra Hall, 36 Battery Place, NYC.

Description:
The break-in at Watergate and the cover-up that followed brought about the resignation of Richard Nixon and created a political shockwave that reverberates to this day.

But declassified White House tapes suggest that the president ordered a single break in—and it was not at the Watergate complex. Join researcher Ken Hughes, “one of America’s foremost experts on secret presidential recordings” (Bob Woodward), as he reveals a long history of illegal activity that prolonged the Vietnam War and was only partly exposed by the Watergate scandal.

 

Brief Bio

Ken Hughes is a researcher at the University of Virginia’s Miller Center Presidential Recordings Program. His work as a journalist has appeared in The New York Times Magazine, the Washington Post, the Boston Globe Magazine and Salon.

Title: The Nixon Tapes, The Chennault Affair, and the Origins of Watergate

Description:
Meet California cookbook authors and winemakers Jeff and Jodie Morgan, taste their award-winning Covenant wines and discover recipes from their newest cookbook: The Covenant Kitchen, Food and Wine for the New Jewish Table (Schocken/OU Press).

The Morgans own Covenant Winery, where they produce what has been described by wine critic Robert Parker as “the greatest kosher wine on Planet Earth.” They now also make wine in Israel, and their international outlook has given them a fresh, new Jewish culinary perspective. Jeff is a former instructor at the Culinary Institute of America and ex-West Coast editor for Wine Spectator Magazine; Jodie is the former Executive Director of the American Institute of Food and Wine (AIWF). Together, this dynamic culinary couple offers a broad array of suggestions for holiday meals—including Passover, Chanukah, Purim and Rosh Hashanah, as well as every day—as they put a new twist on old favorites, with dishes like Flanken Pot au Feu, Gefilte Quenelles and Braised Tuna with Ratatouille. These wine pros will also teach you in a flash, everything you need to know about food and wine pairing. Join the Morgans for a lively discussion, kosher wine tasting and book signing. Their recipes are designed with a kosher kitchen in mind as well.

 

This event is part of our Kitchen Arts & Letters series. In partnership with the esteemed culinary bookstore, we present talks, demos and tastings with leading cookbook authors, chefs, food historians and farmers. See the complete line-up here.

Description:
Internationally beloved opera star Deborah Voigt shares memories and music from her celebrated career, in an intimate account of her life beyond the velvet curtains.

Through anecdotes and backstage stories, she describes her astonishing rise to the operatic heights despite the challenges she faced in private, and performs arias, pop songs, standards and spirituals—all of deep personal significance—in an evening imbued with her trademark warmth, candor and sense of humor. Her new memoir, Call Me Debbie: True Confessions of a Down-to-Earth Diva, will be published in January 2015.

Starring Deborah Voigt
Music Direction by Kevin Stites
Co-Creators: Terrence McNally, Francesca Zambello & Deborah Voigt

This event may not be suitable for younger audiences.

Description:
Allison Williams is best-known as ‘Marnie’ in HBO's critically acclaimed television series, "Girls," embarking on its fourth season.

Williams was recently seen in the title role of the NBC live action event, Peter Pan Live, which aired Dec 4. While she may have found success quickly, Williams has been honing her craft for years. She has been involved in theater since an early age, and while at Yale she refined her improv skills as a member of the improvisational comedy group, Just Add Water. She graduated with a BA in English, and is trained in acting and singing.

Description:
Allan Lokos was on board a plane in Burma on Christmas Day, 2012 when it crashed and exploded in flames. He was severely burned in the accident, and in the days and weeks following, the many doctors who examined Allan determined that he would not survive.

Yet he miraculously survived the crash and now Allan Lokos shares what his long and painful recovery process is teaching him about humanity’s ability to survive—and even thrive—in the face of suffering.

In this inspiring and informative conversation based on his against-all-odds recovery, Allan and renowned meditation teacher and best-selling author, Sharon Salzberg, will examine the challenge of human suffering in general, and address the question of how we can use mindfulness and compassion practices to thrive in the midst of pain and adversity.

Whether your crash is the death of a loved one, a serious illness, loss of financial security or a divorce, this workshop can be truly transformative.

Description:
Join New York Times columnist David Brooks for an in-depth discussion about what constitutes character as explored in his new book.

Some people seem to possess inner lives that are more substantive than the rest of ours. How do they do it? Depth, argues Brooks, is the core of our being and something we cultivate over time; it’s engraved by thought and action; it’s built through the commitments we make—to a nation, a faith, a calling or loved ones—and the sacrifices we endure because of those commitments.
